page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 66: Line 66:
[[Mohamed ElBaradei]] stated on the 9 March 2011 that he would run in the presidential elections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aysor.am/en/news/2011/03/09/egyote-baradei/ |title=ElBaradei to run for president of Egypt â aysor.am â Hot news from Armenia |publisher=aysor.am |accessdate=24 March 2011}}</ref>
[[Mohamed ElBaradei]] stated on the 9 March 2011 that he would run in the presidential elections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aysor.am/en/news/2011/03/09/egyote-baradei/ |title=ElBaradei to run for president of Egypt â aysor.am â Hot news from Armenia |publisher=aysor.am |accessdate=24 March 2011}}</ref>
â
On the 19 March, the [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011|constitutional referendum]] was held, with millions of Egyptians turning up to vote on nine proposed amendments to the constitution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/20113196242356485.html |title=High turnout in Egyptian constitutional poll â Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=19 March 2011 |accessdate=24 March 2011}}</ref> Eager for their first free vote, Egyptians formed long lines outside polling centers to cast their ballots on constitutional amendments that were sponsored by the ruling military.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/tensions-high-as-egyptians-vote-in-first-post-mubarak-referendum-1.350149?localLinksEnabled=false |title=Tensions high as Egyptians vote in first post-Mubarak referendum |publisher=www.Haaretz.com |date=19 March 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> In the lead up to the referendum, there was still dispute amongst the political movements and parties in Egypt about whether they should approve or reject the proposed constitutional amendments. 16 of those political parties and movements, including The Alliance of Women's Organizations, announced that they would reject the proposed amendments and call for the creation of a new constitution. The movements also renewed their calls for protests against the amendments to be held. Supporters of the amendments include the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], the Wasat Party, and the Labor Party.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/360386 |title=Egypt debates upcoming referendum on constitutional amendments |publisher=www.almasryalyoum.com |date=16 March 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> The proposed amendments were limited to nine articles, which many deemed to be insufficient as they failed to limit the power of the president, whilst others argued that the amendments were only a temporary measure and as such did not need to include all the changes that were requested, as the Constitution was to be completely redrafted after the parliamentary and presidential elections. This point has proven to be the most contentious with those who oppose the amendments claiming that a redrafted Constitution will not be representative<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aina.org/news/20110315214029.htm |title=Egypt debates upcoming referendum on constitutional amendments |publisher=www.aina.org |date=16 March 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>with the Egyptian presidential candidate [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] calling on all Egyptians to reject the proposed constitutional amendments, saying that a "Yes" vote will "provide a parliament not representative of the people, composed mainly of members of the National Democratic Party and benefiting businessmen, the opportunity to uphold a Constitution which is also not representative of the people, and this will take us backwards to a great extent.â<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/360150 |title=ElBaradei calls on Egyptians to reject constitutional amendments |publisher=www.almasryalyoum.com |date=16 March 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> ElBaradei was assaulted when he showed up at a school in Moqattam to vote.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-03-19/world/egypt.referendum_1_polling-station-vote-today-egyptians?_s=PM:WORLD |title=ElBaradei attacked trying to vote in Egyptian referendum |publisher=CNN |date=19 March 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
+
On the 19 March, the [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011|constitutional referendum]] was held, with millions of Egyptians turning up to vote on nine proposed amendments to the constitution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/20113196242356485.html |title=High turnout in Egyptian constitutional poll â Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=19 March 2011 |accessdate=24 March 2011}}</ref> Eager for their first free vote, Egyptians formed long lines outside polling centers to cast their ballots on constitutional amendments that were sponsored by the ruling military.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/international/tensions-high-as-egyptians-vote-in-first-post-mubarak-referendum-1.350149?localLinksEnabled=false |title=Tensions high as Egyptians vote in first post-Mubarak referendum |publisher=www.Haaretz.com |date=19 March 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> In the lead up to the referendum, there was still dispute amongst the political movements and parties in Egypt about whether they should approve or reject the proposed constitutional amendments. 16 of those political parties and movements, including The Alliance of Women's Organizations, announced that they would reject the proposed amendments and call for the creation of a new constitution. The movements also renewed their calls for protests against the amendments to be held. Supporters of the amendments include the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], the Wasat Party, and the Labor Party.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/360386 |title=Egypt debates upcoming referendum on constitutional amendments |publisher=www.almasryalyoum.com |date=16 March 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> The proposed amendments were limited to nine articles, which many deemed to be insufficient as they failed to limit the power of the president, whilst others argued that the amendments were only a temporary measure and as such did not need to include all the changes that were requested, as the Constitution was to be completely redrafted after the parliamentary and presidential elections. This point has proven to be the most contentious with those who oppose the amendments claiming that a redrafted Constitution will not be representative<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aina.org/news/20110315214029.htm |title=Egypt debates upcoming referendum on constitutional amendments |publisher=www.aina.org |date=16 March 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> with the Egyptian presidential candidate [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] calling on all Egyptians to reject the proposed constitutional amendments, saying that a "Yes" vote will "provide a parliament not representative of the people, composed mainly of members of the National Democratic Party and benefiting businessmen, the opportunity to uphold a Constitution which is also not representative of the people, and this will take us backwards to a great extent.â<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/360150 |title=ElBaradei calls on Egyptians to reject constitutional amendments |publisher=www.almasryalyoum.com |date=16 March 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref> ElBaradei was assaulted when he showed up at a school in Moqattam to vote.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-03-19/world/egypt.referendum_1_polling-station-vote-today-egyptians?_s=PM:WORLD |title=ElBaradei attacked trying to vote in Egyptian referendum |publisher=CNN |date=19 March 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
The final results of the referendum were announced the next day: 77.2% of Egyptians voted "YES" to constitutional amendments, while 22.8% voted "NO". In total, 18,537,954 Egyptians voted out of around 45m eligible voters, making the turnout 41%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/8125.aspx |title=Egypt referendum results: 77.2 per cent say 'Yes' to the amendments |publisher=english.ahram.org.eg |date=20 March 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
The final results of the referendum were announced the next day: 77.2% of Egyptians voted "YES" to constitutional amendments, while 22.8% voted "NO". In total, 18,537,954 Egyptians voted out of around 45m eligible voters, making the turnout 41%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/8125.aspx |title=Egypt referendum results: 77.2 per cent say 'Yes' to the amendments |publisher=english.ahram.org.eg |date=20 March 2011 |accessdate=1 July 2011}}</ref>
Line 148: Line 148:
On the night of the 10 July, gunmen [[Arab Gas Pipeline|blew up]] an Egyptian [[natural gas]] pipeline to Israel and Jordan in the town of [[El-Arish]] in the [[Sinai Peninsula]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Sweilam |first=Ashraf |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43719969/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/ |title=Gunmen blow up Egyptian gas pipeline to Israel - World news - Mideast/N. Africa - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date= |accessdate=2011-07-12}}</ref> This is the fourth time this has occurred this year and the second time in less than a week
On the night of the 10 July, gunmen [[Arab Gas Pipeline|blew up]] an Egyptian [[natural gas]] pipeline to Israel and Jordan in the town of [[El-Arish]] in the [[Sinai Peninsula]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Sweilam |first=Ashraf |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43719969/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/ |title=Gunmen blow up Egyptian gas pipeline to Israel - World news - Mideast/N. Africa - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date= |accessdate=2011-07-12}}</ref> This is the fourth time this has occurred this year and the second time in less than a week
â
On the 11 July, Prime Minister Essam Sharaf made a televised statement reassuring protesters that the government would respond to public demands and also included a timeline in which these demands would be met. The changes included a new cabinet to be formed within one week and a change in provincial governors before the end of the month. The protesters responded with calls for a million-man march the following day and continuation of their sit-in in Tahrir Square. The Muslim Brotherhood responded that they will not participate in the sit-in. The next morning the SCAF issued a statement<ref>http://www.thememriblog.org/blog_personal/en/39250.htm</ref>, which was perceived as aggressive.<ref>http://axisoflogic.com/artman/publish/Article_63395.shtml</ref>
+
On the 11 July, Prime Minister Essam Sharaf made a televised statement reassuring protesters that the government would respond to public demands and also included a timeline in which these demands would be met. The changes included a new cabinet to be formed within one week and a change in provincial governors before the end of the month. The protesters responded with calls for a million-man march the following day and continuation of their sit-in in Tahrir Square. The Muslim Brotherhood responded that they will not participate in the sit-in. The next morning the SCAF issued a statement,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thememriblog.org/blog_personal/en/39250.htm |title=Military Council in Egypt: We Support The People's Demands; We Will Not Submit to Protestor Violence |publisher=Thememriblog.org |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref> which was perceived as aggressive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://axisoflogic.com/artman/publish/Article_63395.shtml |title=Mass protests continue against Egyptian regimeWith Photo Essay | Egypt |publisher=Axisoflogic.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref>
â
On the 13 July, state television reported that Egypt's government had met a key demand of protesters by firing nearly 700 top police officers in order to cleanse the discredited and widely unpopular force.<ref>http://www.newser.com/article/d9oesgcg2/state-tv-egypt-fires-nearly-700-senior-officers-as-part-of-cleansing-police-force.html</ref> It was also reported that 37 of the dismissed officers face charges of killing protesters. Among those dismissed were 505 major-generals, including 10 of the interior minister's top assistants, 82 colonels and 82 brigadiers.<ref>http://www.newser.com/article/d9oesgcg2/state-tv-egypt-fires-nearly-700-senior-officers-as-part-of-cleansing-police-force.html</ref>
+
On the 13 July, state television reported that Egypt's government had met a key demand of protesters by firing nearly 700 top police officers in order to cleanse the discredited and widely unpopular force.<ref name="newser2">{{cite web|url=http://www.newser.com/article/d9oesgcg2/state-tv-egypt-fires-nearly-700-senior-officers-as-part-of-cleansing-police-force.html |title=State TV: Egypt fires nearly 700 senior officers as part of cleansing police force - 7/13/2011 11:30:46 AM |publisher=Newser |date=2011-07-13 |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref> It was also reported that 37 of the dismissed officers face charges of killing protesters. Among those dismissed were 505 major-generals, including 10 of the interior minister's top assistants, 82 colonels and 82 brigadiers.<ref name="newser2"/>
â
On the 14 July, former President [[Hosni Mubarak]] told prosecutors that he did not order security forces to open fire on protesters during the 18-day uprising that forced him to resign in February. Transcripts of prosecutors questioning Mubarak were published in two Egyptian newspapers but judicial officials confirmed the authenticity of the documents.<ref>http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Egyptian-Media-Mubarak-Denies-Ordering-Police-to-Fire-on-Protesters-125577073.html</ref> Mubarak says he issued clear instructions for police not to use force against people taking part in the protests against his three-decade autocratic rule. He denied charges that he ordered or had knowledge of security forces firing on the demonstrators.<ref>http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Egyptian-Media-Mubarak-Denies-Ordering-Police-to-Fire-on-Protesters-125577073.html</ref>
+
On the 14 July, former President [[Hosni Mubarak]] told prosecutors that he did not order security forces to open fire on protesters during the 18-day uprising that forced him to resign in February. Transcripts of prosecutors questioning Mubarak were published in two Egyptian newspapers but judicial officials confirmed the authenticity of the documents.<ref name="voanews1">{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Egyptian-Media-Mubarak-Denies-Ordering-Police-to-Fire-on-Protesters-125577073.html |title=Egyptian Media: Mubarak Denies Ordering Police to Fire on Protesters | Middle East | English |publisher=Voanews.com |date=2011-07-14 |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref> Mubarak says he issued clear instructions for police not to use force against people taking part in the protests against his three-decade autocratic rule. He denied charges that he ordered or had knowledge of security forces firing on the demonstrators.<ref name="voanews1"/>
â
On the 16 July, a member of Egypt's ruling military council briefly visited a protest camp in a central Cairo square, but left after protesters, some holding up shoes in anger, booed him off a stage. Maj. Gen. Tarek el-Mahdi had come to Tahrir Square to persuade a dozen demonstrators to end a hunger strike which had begun several days ago, but was forced to cut short his visit because of the heckling. El-Mahdi later told state TV that he was disappointed that a small crowd of protesters managed to drive him out of the square before he could reach the tent housing the hunger strikers.<ref>http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43780050/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/</ref> In the latest move to calm rising public anger, Prime Minister [[Essam Sharaf]] accepted the resignation of foreign minister Mohammed el-Orabi. Sharaf also appointed two new deputies, one of which was prominent economist, and former head of the U.N. Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia, Hazem el-Biblawi.<ref>http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43780050/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/|accessdate=17 July 2011</ref>
+
On the 16 July, a member of Egypt's ruling military council briefly visited a protest camp in a central Cairo square, but left after protesters, some holding up shoes in anger, booed him off a stage. Maj. Gen. Tarek el-Mahdi had come to Tahrir Square to persuade a dozen demonstrators to end a hunger strike which had begun several days ago, but was forced to cut short his visit because of the heckling. El-Mahdi later told state TV that he was disappointed that a small crowd of protesters managed to drive him out of the square before he could reach the tent housing the hunger strikers.<ref>{{cite web|last=Deeb |first=Sarah El |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43780050/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/ |title=Senior Egyptian military official heckled - World news - Mideast/N. Africa - msnbc.com |publisher=MSNBC |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref> In the latest move to calm rising public anger, Prime Minister [[Essam Sharaf]] accepted the resignation of foreign minister Mohammed el-Orabi. Sharaf also appointed two new deputies, one of which was prominent economist, and former head of the U.N. Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia, Hazem el-Biblawi.<ref>http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/43780050/ns/world_news-mideast_n_africa/|accessdate=17 July 2011</ref>
â
On the 17 July, Sharaf named 12 new Cabinet members. State TV dubbed the new government lineup the "Revolution Cabinet." Most of the ministers were relative newcomers which was seen as a way to avoid further criticism by the protesters. Even after the Cabinet reshuffle, many of the protesters in the square said they have no intention of calling off their sit-in, which had been in place for more than a week.<ref>http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/07/17/international/i085051D98.DTL</ref> One of the prominent members of the "Revolution Cabinet" is the Chief of Antiquities [[Zahi Hawass]]. Hawass is a prominant member of Egypts archaeological community, but has been the target of protests himself. These protests were begun by archaeology students who accused him of falsely claiming publicity for himself and corruption.
+
On the 17 July, Sharaf named 12 new Cabinet members. State TV dubbed the new government lineup the "Revolution Cabinet." Most of the ministers were relative newcomers which was seen as a way to avoid further criticism by the protesters. Even after the Cabinet reshuffle, many of the protesters in the square said they have no intention of calling off their sit-in, which had been in place for more than a week.<ref name="sfgate1">{{cite web|author=By SARAH EL DEEB, Associated Press |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/07/17/international/i085051D98.DTL |title=Egypt military rulers name electoral council head |publisher=Sfgate.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-19}}</ref> One of the prominent members of the "Revolution Cabinet" is the Chief of Antiquities [[Zahi Hawass]]. Hawass is a prominant member of Egypts archaeological community, but has been the target of protests himself. These protests were begun by archaeology students who accused him of falsely claiming publicity for himself and corruption.
â
Sharaf also accepted the resignation of Finance Minister Samir Radwan (the reason for his resignation was due to the fact that his new budget was deemed by many protestors to be too conservative in dealing with the poverty which had been one of the main catalysts of the uprising) and the foreign minister, who was replaced by the former ambassador to Saudia Arabia, Mohammed Kamel Omar. Radwan's position was taken by prominent economist Hazem el-Biblawi, who had also been appointed deputy prime minister. There were also changes in the ministries of transport, military production, higher education, communication, agriculture, health, religious endowments, local development, trade and industry and civil aviation, with ministers being replaced<ref>http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2011/07/17/international/i085051D98.DTL</ref>.
+
Sharaf also accepted the resignation of Finance Minister Samir Radwan (the reason for his resignation was due to the fact that his new budget was deemed by many protestors to be too conservative in dealing with the poverty which had been one of the main catalysts of the uprising) and the foreign minister, who was replaced by the former ambassador to Saudia Arabia, Mohammed Kamel Omar. Radwan's position was taken by prominent economist Hazem el-Biblawi, who had also been appointed deputy prime minister. There were also changes in the ministries of transport, military production, higher education, communication, agriculture, health, religious endowments, local development, trade and industry and civil aviation, with ministers being replaced.<ref name="sfgate1"/>
